questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with progressive memory decline and difficulty performing daily tasks. Neuroimaging shows significant atrophy in the medial temporal lobe, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis reveals high levels of certain neurotoxic oligomers. Which of the following statements regarding the pathology and pathophysiology of this patient’s condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Soluble neurotoxic oligomers lead to synapse loss.

options.label: B
options.text: Neurofibrillary tangles contain hyperphosphorylated tau protein.

options.label: C
options.text: Plaques indicate polymerization of the neurotoxic proteins.

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased acetylcholine, norepinephrine and serotonin.
questions.explanation:
Macroscopic Pathology
  • Earliest degeneration: Seen in the medial temporal lobe (entorhinal/perirhinal cortex and hippocampus), inferolateral temporal cortex, and nucleus basalis of Meynert.
  • Amyloid plaques: Formed by amyloid beta (Aβ), proteoglycans, ApoE, α-antichymotrypsin, and other proteins.
  • Amyloid angiopathy: Accumulation of Aβ in cerebral arterioles.

Microscopic Pathology
  • Neuritic plaques: Central core of amyloid surrounded by dystrophic neurites and activated microglia.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs): Composed of abnormally hyperphosphorylated tau protein, which forms paired helical filaments. (Option B ruled out)
  • Tau pathology: Hyperphosphorylated tau compromises microtubule function and leads to neuronal dysfunction.
  • Coexisting pathologies: Often seen with DLB, TDP-43, or vascular pathology.

Neurotransmitters
  • Acetylcholine reduction: Due to degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.
  • Noradrenergic and serotonergic depletion: From degeneration in the locus coeruleus (norepinephrine) and dorsal raphe (serotonin).
  • Cognitive deficits: Linked to the reduction of acetylcholine and dysfunction in the cholinergic system.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife due to recent personality changes. She reports that he has become impulsive, shows poor judgment in social situations, and has difficulty planning and organizing tasks. His medical history is significant for a car accident 6 months ago. On examination, he shows emotional lability and perseveration. Which area of the brain is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Area

Functions

Symptoms when Damaged

Ventromedial Orbitofrontal Cortex
  • Social behavior
  • Impulse control
  • Decision making
  • Emotional regulation
  • Impulsivity
  • Poor social judgment
  • Emotional lability
  • Disinhibition

Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex
  • Working memory
  • Planning
  • Attention
  • Problem-solving
  • Difficulty with planning and organization
  • Poor working memory
  • Reduced motivation (abulia)
  • Perseveration

Anterior Cingulate Cortex
  • Motivation
  • Error detection
  • Emotional processing
  • Apathy
  • Reduced initiative
  • Difficulty with emotional regulation

Broca's Area (Left Frontal Lobe)
  • Speech production
  • Expressive aphasia (non-fluent)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by his family due to confusion, difficulty walking, and memory problems. On examination, he is disoriented to time and place, has difficulty recalling recent events, and shows signs of confabulation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Amnestic Disorder

Cause

Key Features

Korsakoff Syndrome

Thiamine deficiency, often due to chronic alcoholism

• Anterograde and retrograde amnesia

• Confabulation

• Personality changes

• Often follows Wernicke encephalopathy

Transient Global Amnesia

Unknown, possibly related to temporal lobe ischemia

• Sudden onset of anterograde amnesia

• Episodes last 6-24 hours

• Complete recovery is typical

Head Injury-Related Amnesia

Traumatic brain injury

• Retrograde amnesia for events leading up to injury

• Anterograde amnesia post-injury

• Severity correlates with injury severity

Cerebrovascular Disease-Related Amnesia

Infarctions affecting hippocampus or thalamus

• Memory impairment

• Often accompanied by other focal neurological signs

Alcoholic Blackouts

Acute alcohol intoxication

• Inability to remember events during intoxication

• Awareness of memory gap upon sobering

ECT-Related Amnesia

Electroconvulsive therapy

• Retrograde amnesia for minutes before treatment

• Anterograde amnesia after treatment

• Usually resolves within hours to months

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter due to progressive memory loss and confusion over the past year. She has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management Strategy

Details

Pharmacological
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine - used as a transdermal patch, galantamine) for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease
  • Memantine - blocks NMDA glutamate receptors, for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease (Option A)
  • Antidepressants for comorbid depression
  • Antipsychotics (with caution) for severe behavioral disturbances

Non-pharmacological
  • Cognitive stimulation therapy
  • Reality orientation
  • Reminiscence therapy
  • Behavioral management techniques
  • Physical exercise programs

Environmental Modifications
  • Simplify the living environment
  • Use memory aids (e.g., calendars, to-do lists)
  • Ensure adequate lighting
  • Remove potential hazards

Caregiver Support
  • Education about the disease
  • Respite care
  • Support groups
  • Counseling

Newly approved drugs for treatment of early Alzheimer's disease.
  • Aducanumab (Aduhelm) - Monoclonal antibody targeting amyloid-beta plaques.
  • Lecanemab (Leqembi) - Monoclonal antibody targeting soluble amyloid-beta protofibrils, facilitating plaque clearance.
  • Donanemab - Monoclonal antibody targeting amyloid plaques; selectively binds to a modified form of amyloid-beta.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her son due to concerns about her memory. The physician decides to administer the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE). Which of the following statements about the MMSE is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It was originally designed to identify early stages of dementia

options.label: B
options.text: It takes approximately 30 minutes to administer

options.label: C
options.text: A score of 23/24 is traditionally used as a cut-off for suspected cognitive impairment

options.label: D
options.text: The test protocol and variables are the same for different socio-geographic populations

questions.correct_answer: C. A score of 23/24 is traditionally used as a cut-off for suspected cognitive impairment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive cognitive decline over the past 6 months. He has difficulty with memory, confusion, and occasional myoclonic jerks. His medical history is unremarkable, but his wife mentions he was an avid hunter who often consumed venison. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Neurocognitive Disorder due to Traumatic Brain Injury

options.label: B
options.text: Neurocognitive Disorder due to HIV Infection

options.label: C
options.text: Neurocognitive Disorder due to Prion Disease

questions.correct_answer: C. Neurocognitive Disorder due to Prion Disease
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Due to Traumatic Brain Injury

Due to HIV Infection

Due to Prion Disease

History

H/O traumatic brain injury, with associated noncognitive symptoms

HIV diagnosis, Associated cognitive symptoms

Cognitive impairment: Subtle onset, Rapid progression

Key Symptoms
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Amnesia following trauma
  • Confusion/ disorientation
  • Neuroimaging evidence of injury/ Neurologic symptoms
  • Cognitive symptoms associated with HIV infection
  • May include memory issues, attention deficits, and slowed processing speed
  • Rapid cognitive decline
  • Motor symptoms (e.g., myoclonus/ ataxia)
  • Biochemical marker on testing

Onset

Acute, following traumatic event

Gradual, as HIV progresses

Subtle onset, but rapid progression

Course

Can improve, stabilize, or worsen over time

Often fluctuates with HIV treatment and progression

Progressive rapid decline

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the clinic with noticeable cognitive decline. She is diagnosed with Dementia with Lewy Bodies. Which of the following is not a core feature of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Core Features

Supporting Features
  • Fluctuating levels of attention and alertness (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations (Option B ruled out)
  • Parkinsonian features (e.g., cogwheeling, bradykinesia, resting tremor) (Option D ruled out)
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Repeated falls
  • Syncope
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics
  • Systematized delusions (Option C)
  • Hallucinations in other modalities (e.g., auditory, tactile)

Feature

Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)

Parkinson's Disease (PD)

Onset of Symptoms

Cognitive and psychiatric symptoms appear early; motor symptoms develop later.

Primarily motor symptoms appear first (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors).

Visual Hallucinations

Common and can occur early.

Less common initially; may occur later, often due to treatment.

Fluctuations in Attention

Fluctuations in alertness and attention are characteristic.

Fluctuations are primarily related to medication cycles.

Response to Medications

Poor response to dopaminergic medications; risk of worsening psychiatric symptoms.

Generally improves with dopaminergic medications (e.g., levodopa).

Sleep Disturbances

REM sleep behavior disorder is common and can precede cognitive symptoms.

REM sleep behavior disorder may occur but is primarily linked to motor symptoms.

Progression

Rapid progression of cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Gradual progression of motor symptoms, with cognitive decline developing later.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with noticeable personality changes, including increased impulsivity and a lack of empathy towards his family. He has difficulty regulating his emotions and exhibits hyperorality, often eating unusual food combinations. His cognitive functions related to memory and perception appear preserved. A family history of similar symptoms is noted. Based on the presented symptoms, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Behavioral Variant

Language Variant

Affected

Social cognition/executive function

Language (word finding, naming, grammar, less spontaneous speech)

Spared

Learning/memory/perceptual-motor function

Learning/memory/perceptual-motor function

Associated Symptoms (≥3)
  • Disinhibition
  • Apathy
  • Lack of sympathy/empathy
  • Perseveration/stereotypies
  • Hyperorality/dietary changes

N/A

Probable
  • Evidence of a genetic cause (family history/genetic testing)
  • Neuroimaging evidence of frontal/temporal pathology

Possible

Some but not all the probable criteria met

Cause of Dementia

Clinical Features

Alzheimer's Disease
  • Gradual memory loss. Memory impairment is usually the first symptom
  • Difficulty with problem-solving and disorientation
  • Presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles on brain imaging or autopsy
  • Irreversible; progressive neurodegeneration

Vascular Dementia
  • Cognitive decline following a stroke (CT/MRI showing infarcts)
  • Fluctuating abilities
  • Impaired judgment
  • Potentially reversible if acute vascular events are treated promptly

Lewy Body Dementia
  • Hallucinations occurring early - Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (tremors, rigidity)
  • Fluctuating cognition
  • REM sleep behavior disorder
  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotics
  • Irreversible; symptomatic treatments may help manage symptoms

Frontotemporal Dementia
  • Early onset (often under 65 years)
  • Language difficulties and disinhibition
  • Significant changes in social behavior or personality
  • Irreversible; progressive condition

Alcohol-Related Dementia
  • Memory problems and history of alcohol abuse
  • Difficulty with planning and organization
  • Social withdrawal
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)
  • Potentially reversible with abstinence and nutritional support

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease
  • Rapidly progressive dementia
  • Myoclonus
  • Visual disturbances
  • Diagnosis confirmed via MRI (increased signal in basal ganglia) and EEG findings
  • Rare, irreversible; rapidly progressive and fatal

Pick's Disease
  • Marked personality changes
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Emotional blunting
  • MRI/CT shows frontal and temporal lobe atrophy
  • Behavioral changes prominent early
  • Irreversible; part of the frontotemporal dementia spectrum

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension is evaluated for cognitive decline. His family reports that he has had several episodes of confusion and difficulty with problem-solving. Neurological examination reveals evidence of white matter changes on MRI and he has a history of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following features is MOST characteristic of vascular dementia in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Continuous and gradual decline in cognitive function.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive changes following a stroke only.

options.label: C
options.text: Stepwise deterioration in cognitive abilities over time.

options.label: D
options.text: Memory loss as the only symptom.

questions.correct_answer: C. Stepwise deterioration in cognitive abilities over time.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the key difference between twilight state and oneiroid state?

options.label: A
options.text: The twilight state is characterized by disturbed consciousness with unexpected violent acts, while the oneiroid state involves a more dream-like, less interactive experience.

options.label: B
options.text: The oneiroid state features disorientation and confusion, whereas the twilight state is marked by clarity and coherence.

options.label: C
options.text: In the twilight state, individuals are typically fully unconscious, while those in the oneiroid the state exhibit fluctuating consciousness

options.label: D
options.text: The oneiroid state is primarily associated with external stimuli, while the twilight state is largely independent of environmental factors.

questions.correct_answer: A. The twilight state is characterized by disturbed consciousness with unexpected violent acts, while the oneiroid state involves a more dream-like, less interactive experience.
questions.explanation:
Level of Consciousness

Features

Alertness
  • Normal cognitive function
  • Fully awake and aware of the environment
  • Appropriate responses to stimuli
  • Ability to maintain attention.

Lethargy (Somnolence)
  • Drowsy but can be awakened
  • Decreased alertness
  • Slow responses to questions
  • May fall asleep easily
  • Requires external stimulation to maintain wakefulness.

Obtundation
  • Reduced awareness and responsiveness
  • Difficult to arouse
  • Responses are slowed
  • The individual may appear confused or disoriented.

Stupor (Semicoma)
  • Near-unresponsive state;
  • Can only be aroused with vigorous or painful stimuli.
  • With no awareness of the environment.

Coma
  • Unresponsive state
  • Cannot be aroused even with strong stimuli.
  • No voluntary responses
  • Brain activity may still be present at a basic level (reflexes may occur).

Torpor
  • A state of physical and mental inactivity, often due to fatigue or metabolic disturbances.
  • Reduced responsiveness
  • The individual may appear lethargic and is difficult to arouse without significant stimuli.

Twilight
  • A transitional state between alertness and lethargy, characterized by confusion and disorientation.
  • Responses may be variable
  • Onset/end- Abrupt
  • Episodes of unexpected violent acts/ emotional outbursts.
  • The individual may exhibit impaired judgment and perception of reality.

Oneiroid State
  • A dream-like state with vivid hallucinations
  • The individual may be unaware of their surroundings.
  • Experiences of hallucinations or delusions, leading to a distorted perception of reality
  • Unresponsive to external stimuli.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive memory loss over the past year, along with increasing difficulty in planning and organizing daily tasks. Her family reports that she often misplaces items and struggles to follow conversations. Which of the following genes does NOT cause early-onset of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (EOAD)

Late-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (LOAD)
  • APP gene (chromosome 21): Associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease (FAD) and Down's syndrome. (Option A ruled out)
  • Presenilin-1 (PSEN-1): Most common cause (40-70%), mean onset at 45 years, rapid progression (6-7 years) (Option B ruled out).
  • Presenilin-2 (PSEN-2): Less common, mean onset at 53 years, slower progression (11 years). (Option D ruled out)
  • Pathogenesis involves mutations that increase Aβ42 levels and amyloid accumulation.
  • APOE gene (chromosome 19) is a key risk factor.
  • ApoE ε4 allele: Increases risk and lowers age of onset (about 10 years per allele).
  • ApoE ε2 allele: May reduce risk.
  • Risk varies by ethnicity; higher in East Asians, lower in Blacks and Hispanics.
  • Polygenic Risk: Additional genes (e.g., CLU, PICALM, CR1) involved, with smaller individual effects. Variants in TREM2 significantly increase AD risk (odds ratios 3-4).

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with progressive memory loss, difficulty concentrating, and irritability over the past several months. His family reports recent weight loss and changes in appetite. On examination, he appears pale, and neurological examination shows no focal deficits. Basic laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his cognitive decline?
questions.explanation:
Degenerative dementias

  • Alzheimer disease
  • Frontotemporal dementias (e.g., Pick disease)
  • Parkinson disease
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Idiopathic cerebral ferrocalcinosis (Fahr disease)
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Limbic predominant age-related TDP-43 encephalopathy (LATE)

Miscellaneous
  • Huntington disease
  • Wilson disease
  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy
  • Neuroacanthocytosis

Psychiatric
  • Pseudodementia of depression
  • Cognitive decline in late-life schizophrenia

Demyelinating diseases
  • Multiple sclerosis

Cardiac, vascular, and anoxia
  • Infarction (single or multiple or strategic lacunar)
  • Binswanger disease (subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy)
  • Hemodynamic insufficiency (e.g., hypoperfusion or hypoxia)

Physiologic
  • Normal pressure hydrocephalus

Metabolic
  • Vitamin deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, folate)
  • Endocrinopathies (e.g., hypothyroidism)
  • Chronic metabolic disturbances (e.g., uremia)

Tumor
  • Primary or metastatic (e.g., meningioma or metastatic breast or lung cancer)

Traumatic
  • Dementia pugilistica, posttraumatic dementia
  • Subdural hematoma

Infection
  • Prion diseases (e.g., Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease, bovine spongiform encephalitis, Gerstmann–Sträussler syndrome)
  • Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)
  • Syphilis

Drugs and toxins
  • Alcohol
  • Heavy metals
  • Irradiation
  • Cognitive dysfunction due to medications (e.g., anticholinergics)
  • Carbon monoxide

Cause of Dementia

Clinical Features

Alzheimer's Disease
  • Gradual memory loss.
  • Memory impairment is usually the first symptom
  • Difficulty with problem-solving and disorientation
  • Presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles on brain imaging or autopsy
  • Irreversible; progressive neurodegeneration

Vascular Dementia
  • Cognitive decline following a stroke (CT/MRI showing infarcts)
  • Fluctuating abilities
  • Impaired judgment
  • Potentially reversible if acute vascular events are treated promptly

Lewy Body Dementia
  • Hallucinations occurring early - Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (tremors, rigidity)
  • Fluctuating cognition
  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotics
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Irreversible; symptomatic treatments may help manage symptoms

Frontotemporal Dementia
  • Early onset (often under 65 years)
  • Language difficulties and disinhibition
  • Significant changes in social behavior or personality
  • Irreversible; progressive condition

Alcohol-Related Dementia
  • Memory problems and history of alcohol abuse
  • Difficulty with planning and organization
  • Social withdrawal
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)
  • Potentially reversible with abstinence and nutritional support

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease
  • Rapidly progressive dementia
  • Myoclonus
  • Visual disturbances
  • Diagnosis confirmed via MRI (increased signal in basal ganglia) and EEG findings
  • Rare, irreversible; rapidly progressive and fatal

Pick's Disease
  • Marked personality changes
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Emotional blunting
  • MRI/CT shows frontal and temporal lobe atrophy
  • Behavioral changes prominent early
  • Irreversible; part of the frontotemporal dementia spectrum

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought in due to progressive memory loss over two years. She frequently forgets recent events, misplaces items, and has become socially withdrawn. Neurological exam shows intact motor function but poor recall after 5 minutes and disorientation to time. Blood work and imaging are unremarkable. Which of the following is not a typical feature of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid onset and fluctuation of symptoms

questions.correct_answer: C. Rapid onset and fluctuation of symptoms
questions.explanation:
• Alzheimer’s Disease
  • Vascular Dementia
  • Dementia with Lewy Bodies
  • Frontotemporal Dementia
  • Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
  • HIV-associated Dementia
  • Prion Diseases
  • Parkinson’s Disease
  • Huntington’s Disease

Memory Impairment
  • Early signs include difficulty recalling recent events, conversations, or tasks (e.g., forgetting appointments, misplacing items).
  • Over time, even long-term memories may be lost, and patients may forget personal details like their birthplace or the names of close relatives.

Impaired Attention and Executive Functioning
  • Patients struggle with tasks requiring planning, decision-making, and problem-solving.
  • This impairment affects their ability to perform activities of daily living, such as managing finances, cooking, or following a schedule.

Disorientation
  • Patients may become disoriented to time, place, or person.
  • For example, they may forget where they are or be unable to find their way back to their room after using the bathroom.

Language Deficits (Aphasia)
  • Difficulty in finding the right words, naming objects, or following a conversation is common, especially in cortical dementias like Alzheimer's disease.
  • As the condition progresses, speech may become nonsensical or fragmented.

Personality and Behavioral Changes (Option D)
  • Some patients become socially withdrawn, while others exhibit agitation, irritability, or aggression.
  • Disinhibition and inappropriate behavior can occur.
  • Patients with psychotic symptoms may develop paranoid delusions or hallucinations. (Most common is the delusion of persecution).

Mood and Emotional Changes
  • Depression and anxiety are common.
  • Patients may also experience emotional lability, swinging between laughing and crying without obvious triggers.

Motor Symptoms
  • Motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia can accompany cognitive decline in certain types of dementia, like Parkinson’s disease or Lewy body dementia.
  • Neurologic findings such as seizures or primitive reflexes (e.g., grasp reflex) may appear in some patients.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female is brought by her daughter, who reports that her mother has been progressively forgetting names, events, and sometimes even familiar faces over the last year. Recently, she misplaced household items and became suspicious of neighbors, accusing them of stealing. The patient is oriented to time and place but cannot recall what she had for breakfast. Her mood appears stable, and she does not report hearing voices or seeing things. There is no history of psychiatric illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Delirium

Dementia

Schizophrenia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Gradual (months to years)

Gradual (late adolescence/adulthood)

Course

Fluctuates (worse at night)

Progressive, stable day-to-day

Chronic, can have relapses

Attention

Impaired

Initially normal, impaired later

Usually intact

Orientation

Disoriented

Mostly intact until late stages

Intact

Hallucinations

Visual, tactile (common)

Rare

Auditory (common)

Memory

Short-term impaired

Long-term impaired

Intact (except in psychosis)

Consciousness

Fluctuating

Normal until late stages

Normal

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes is admitted to the hospital for pneumonia. Three days into the hospital stay, he becomes acutely confused, disoriented to time and place, and exhibits fluctuating levels of consciousness. The patient is agitated, pulling at his IV lines, and experiencing visual hallucinations. His family reports he was mentally alert prior to admission. The patient's vital signs show fever and tachycardia. His medication list includes antibiotics, antihypertensives, and metformin. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Rule out metabolic and infectious causes

questions.correct_answer: C. Rule out metabolic and infectious causes

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes is admitted to the hospital for pneumonia. On the second day of hospitalization, he becomes confused, agitated, and disoriented to time and place. His family reports that he was cognitively intact before admission. He is unable to focus on simple tasks and frequently hallucinates. His symptoms fluctuate throughout the day, worsening at night. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.explanation:
Feature

Delirium (Option A)

Dementia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Insidious, progressive (months to years)

Duration

Short-term (hours to weeks)

Long-term (months to years)

Course

Fluctuating, worse at night (sundowning)

Steady, progressive deterioration

Consciousness

Impaired, fluctuating levels of alertness

Clear until late stages

Attention

Markedly impaired

Normal until later stages

Memory Impairment

Short-term memory is severely impaired

Short-term memory loss in the early stages, long-term memory affected later

Hallucinations/Delusions

Common, often visual or tactile

Uncommon in early stages, may occur in advanced stages

Sleep-Wake Cycle

Disrupted (e.g., insomnia, daytime drowsiness, reversal of sleep cycle)

Sleep disturbances occur late in the disease

EEG Findings

Abnormal, showing diffuse slowing

Normal in early stages; slowing in late stages

questions.text: A 45-year-old man came to OPD with complaints of impaired consciousness, confusion, inattention, disorganized thinking, and visual hallucination, with symptoms more at night. Which clinical feature is most characteristic of this psychiatric condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Delirium

Dementia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Insidious, progressive (months to years)

Duration

Short-term (hours to weeks)

Long-term (months to years)

Course

Fluctuating, worse at night (sundowning)

Steady, progressive deterioration

Consciousness

Impaired, fluctuating levels of alertness

Clear until late stages

Attention

Markedly impaired

Normal until later stages

Memory Impairment

Short-term memory is severely impaired

Short-term memory loss in the early stages, long-term memory affected later

Hallucinations/Delusions

Common, often visual or tactile

Uncommon in early stages, may occur in advanced stages

Sleep-Wake Cycle

Disrupted (e.g., insomnia, daytime drowsiness, reversal of sleep cycle)

Sleep disturbances occur late in the disease

EEG Findings

Abnormal, showing diffuse slowing

Normal in early stages; slowing in late stages

Drugs
  • Alcohol
  • Sedatives
  • Antidepressants

Endocrinal
  • Hypothyroidism/hyperthyroidism
  • Hypopituitarism/hyperpituitarism

Liver
  • Hepatic encephalopathy

Infections
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonia

Renal
  • Uremic Encephalopathy

Intracranial
  • Epilepsy
  • Tumors
  • Injury

Others
  • Heat
  • Sleep deprivation

Metabolic
  • Hypoxia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Electrolyte imbalance

Type of Delirium

Causes

Hypoactive Delirium
  • Electrolyte imbalances, hypoglycemia, hepatic encephalopathy, uremia
  • Urinary tract infections, pneumonia, sepsis
  • Stroke, traumatic brain injury, dementia
  • Sedatives (benzodiazepines, opioids), anticholinergics, psychotropic medications
  • Heart failure, respiratory failure, dehydration

Hyperactive Delirium
  • Alcohol withdrawal, withdrawal from benzodiazepines or sedatives
  • Stimulants (cocaine, amphetamines), hallucinogens (LSD, PCP)
  • Hyperthyroidism, fever or infection (sepsis)
  • Traumatic brain injury, encephalitis
  • Anticholinergics, stimulants

Mixed Delirium
  • Acute severe infections (pneumonia, sepsis), post-surgical states
  • Mixed electrolyte imbalances, liver or renal failure
  • Combination of sedatives and stimulants.
  • Dementia with acute exacerbation, delirium superimposed on chronic cognitive decline
